title: Pioneers of the Revolution
text:
The Pioneers of the Revolution () was a youth organisation in <a href="Burkina%20Faso">Burkina Faso</a>, modelled along the pattern of the <a href="pioneer%20movement">pioneer movement</a>s typically operated by <a href="Communism">communist</a> parties, such as the contemporary <a href="Pioneers%20of%20Enver">Pioneers of Enver</a>, <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Mart%C3%AD%20Pioneer%20Organization">José Martí Pioneer Organisation</a> and <a href="Agostinho%20Neto%20Pioneer%20Organization">Agostinho Neto Pioneer Organisation</a>. The Pioneers of the Revolution organised children of all ages. Much like many other young pioneer movements, such as the <a href="Vladimir%20Lenin%20All-Union%20Pioneer%20Organization">Vladimir Lenin All-Union Pioneer Organisation</a> and the <a href="Young%20Pioneers%20of%20China">Young Pioneers of China</a>, the most distinct sign of the Pioneers were their red scarves, joined by rudimentary uniforms and <a href="Beret%23As%20a%20revolutionary%20symbol">yellow berets</a>.
The movement was founded by Captain <a href="Thomas%20Sankara">Thomas Sankara</a>, a <a href="Marxism">Marxist</a> and <a href="Pan-Africanism">pan-Africanist</a> revolutionary who came to power in what was then the <a href="Republic%20of%20Upper%20Volta">Republic of Upper Volta</a> after a popularly-supported coup in 1983. Sankara undertook what he called the "Democratic and Popular Revolution" (), a radical transformation of society. Many of the measures taken by Sankara and his Council of Popular Salvation junta were concerned with children – for example, <a href="female%20genital%20mutilation">female genital mutilation</a> and <a href="forced%20marriage">forced marriage</a>s were banned, a nationwide literacy campaign was held, and approximately 2.5 million children were vaccinated against <a href="meningitis">meningitis</a>, <a href="yellow%20fever">yellow fever</a> and <a href="measles">measles</a>.
Other entities created by Sankara's government included the <a href="Committees%20for%20the%20Defense%20of%20the%20Revolution%20%28Burkina%20Faso%29">Committees for the Defense of the Revolution</a>, which many Pioneers belonged to as well, and the <a href="Popular%20Revolutionary%20Tribunal%20%28Burkina%20Faso%29">Popular Revolutionary Tribunals</a>. Much like the Committees and the Tribunals, the Pioneers of the Revolution were abolished after Thomas Sankara was killed in 1987 by a military coup led by his former friend and colleague <a href="Blaise%20Compaor%C3%A9">Blaise Compaoré</a>, who would remain in power until his own overthrow in the <a href="2014%20Burkinab%C3%A9%20uprising">2014 Burkinabé uprising</a>. One of the primary opposition groups against Compaoré's government was the <a href="Le%20Balai%20Citoyen">Citizens' Broom</a> (). Its leader, the musician <a href="Sams%E2%80%99K%20Le%20Jah">Sams’K Le Jah</a>, stated in a 2014 interview that he received his political education as a teenager in Sankara's pioneer youth movement.
